CHAPTER 844: COMMERCIAL SOLICITATION AND OTHER DOOR-TO-DOOR CANVASSING
Section
844.01   Purpose
844.02   Definitions
844.03   Commercial solicitation license required
844.04   Application for commercial solicitation license
844.05   Investigation and issuance of license for commercial solicitation
844.06   Bond for commercial solicitation
844.07   Badges for commercial solicitation
844.08   Exhibition of license
844.09   Duty of police to enforce
844.10   Records
844.11   Revocation of license
844.12   Appeal
844.13   Expiration of license
844.14   Sales on public property
844.15   Time restrictions for commercial solicitation
844.16   Private citizens may prohibit door-to-door canvassing
844.17   Exemptions
844.18   Organizational liability
 
844.99   Penalty
§ 844.01  PURPOSE.
   The United States Supreme Court has recognized that door-to-door canvassers,
"whether selling pots or distributing leaflets, may lessen the peaceful
enjoyment of a home," and that "burglars frequently pose as canvassers, either
in order that they may have a pretense to discover whether a house is empty and
hence ripe for burglary, or for the purpose of spying out the premises in order
that they may return later." Martin v. City of Struthers, 319 U.S. 141,144
(1943). These problems continue to be associated with door-to-door, as are even
graver ones. Therefore, the  public purpose of this Chapter is to vigorously
protect the First Amendment right of free speech and its accompanying promise
of anonymity for the door-to-door canvassers, while prudently balancing that
right with the government's equally important role in preventing fraud,
minimizing crime, protecting the personal security of its citizens, and above
all, facilitating every citizen's personal right to privacy.
(Ord. 2008-49, passed 9-16-2008)
§ 844.02  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CANVASSER.  Any individual who enters upon private property without
invitation or permission for the purposes of door-to-door canvassing as defined
above.
   CHARITABLE/RELIGIOUS/POLITICAL SOLICITATION. Door-to-door canvassing by any
person, the primary purpose of which is to solicit funds or sell goods for the
benefit of charitable or not-for-profit organizations, or for the purpose of
providing information, either written or oral, to the occupants of the dwelling
about candidates for public office, political issues, or religious or church
related matters.
   COMMERCIAL SOLICITATION. The act of door-to-door canvassing for the purpose
of soliciting orders for or making sales of goods, wares, merchandise, or
service, or seeking donations or raising funds for any cause or organization
for profit without prior appointment or permission of the occupant or occupants
of such dwellings and which is not charitable/religious/political solicitation.
   DOOR-TO-DOOR CANVASSING.    Entering upon  private property and/or private
residences with the purpose of contacting the occupants thereof either face-to-
face, by depositing documents at the residence, or both, but without invitation
or permission to do so by the owners or occupants of such private property or
residences. This shall include but not be limited to such activities that are
for the purpose of advertising, promoting, selling, explaining and/or
proselytizing any product, service, organization or cause, or for the purpose
of surveying or poll-taking. DOOR-TO-DOOR CANVASSING shall include both
commercial solicitation and charitable/religious/political solicitation. It is
not the purpose of this chapter to regulate activities such as a mail carrier
or meter reader entering upon private property in performance of his or her
duties, or other similar persons where permission to enter property is implied
by the service rendered.
(Ord. 2008-49, passed 9-16-2008)
§ 844.03  COMMERCIAL SOLICITATION LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No individual shall conduct commercial solicitation in the village without
first obtaining a license to do so as provided in this chapter.
(Ord. 2008-49, passed 9-16-2008)
§ 844.04  APPLICATION FOR COMMERCIAL SOLICITATION LICENSE.
   (a)   Each applicant for license for commercial solicitation under this
chapter must file with the Village Administrative Office a sworn application in
writing (in duplicate) on a form to be furnished by the Village Administrative
Office which shall give the following information:
      (1)   Name, description, and date of birth of applicant;
      (2)   Permanent home address and full local address of the applicant;
      (3)   A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to
be sold;
      (4)   If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with
credentials establishing the exact relationship;
      (5)   The length of time for which the right to do business is desired;
      (6)   The place where the goods or property proposed to be sold, or
orders taken for the sale thereof, are manufactured or produced, where the
goods or products are located at the time the application is filed, and the
proposed method of delivery;
      (7)   A photograph of the applicant taken within 60 days immediately
prior to the date of the filing of the application, which picture shall be two
inches by two inches showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear
and distinguishing manner;
      (8)   A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted
of any crime, misdemeanor, or violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature
of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefore.
   (b)   At the time of filing the application, a fee of $150 shall be paid to
the Village Administrative Office to cover the cost of investigation of the
facts stated therein.
(Ord. 2008-49, passed 9-16-2008; Am. Ord. 2018-27, passed 7-9-2018)
§ 844.05  INVESTIGATION AND ISSUANCE OF LICENSE FOR COMMERCIAL SOLICITATION.
   (a)   Upon receipt of the application for commercial solicitation license,
the original shall be referred to the Chief of Police, who shall determine
whether the application is complete based upon the requirements provided in §
844.04, and shall promptly notify the applicant of any deficiencies in the
application;
   (b)   If the Chief of Police determines that the application is complete,
the Chief of Police shall cause the investigation of the applicant to be made
and shall have ten calendar days within which to make a decision based on the
provisions in divisions (c) and (d) of this section as to whether to grant or
deny the application for a commercial solicitation license.
   (c)   If as a result of the investigation, it is determined that the
applicant has been convicted of a crime related to deception, fraud, sex
offenses, or other crime of moral turpitude, the Chief of Police shall endorse
on the application his or her disapproval and his or her reasons for the same,
and return the application to the Mayor or his or her designee, who shall
notify the applicant that his or her application is disapproved and that no
license will be issued.
   (d)   If as a result of the investigation, no conviction as detailed in
division (b) of this section is discovered, the Chief of Police shall endorse
on the application his or her approval, execute a permit addressed to the
applicant for the carrying on of the business applied for and return the
permit, along with the application, to the Mayor or his or her designee, who
shall deliver to the applicant his or her permit and issue a license. The
license shall contain the signature and seal of the issuing officer and shall
show the name, address and photograph of the licensee, the class of the license
issued and either the kind of goods to be sold under the license, and the
amount of fee paid, the date of issuance and the length of time the same shall
be operative, as well as the license number and other identifying description
of any vehicle used in such soliciting or canvassing. The Mayor or his or her
designee shall keep a permanent record of all licenses issued.
(Ord. 2008-49, passed 9-16-2008; Am. Ord. 2018-27, passed 7-9-2018)
§ 844.06  BOND FOR COMMERCIAL SOLICITATION.
   Every applicant for commercial solicitation, not a resident of the village
or who being a resident of the village represents a firm whose principal place
of business is located outside the state, shall file with the Mayor or his or
her designee a surety bond, running to the village in the amount of $ 1,000,
with surety acceptable to and approved by the Mayor or his or her designee,
conditioned that the applicant shall comply fully with all the ordinances of
the village and the statues of the state regulating and concerning the business
of solicitor and guaranteeing to any citizen of the village that all money paid
as a down payment will be accounted for and applied according to the
representation of the solicitor and further guaranteeing to any citizen of the
village doing business with the solicitor that the property purchased will be
delivered according to the representations of the solicitor. Action on such
bond may be brought in the name of the village to the use or benefit of the
aggrieved person or persons.
(Ord. 2008-49, passed 9-16-2008)
§ 844.07  BADGES FOR COMMERCIAL SOLICITATION.
   The Mayor or his or her designee shall issue to each licensee at the time of
delivery of his or her license a badge which shall contain the words "licensed
solicitor," the period for which the license is issued and the number of the
license, in letters and figures easily discernible from a distance of ten feet.
The badge shall, during the time the license is effective, be displayed on the
front of his or her outer garment in a way as to be conspicuous.
(Ord. 2008-49, passed 9-16-2008)
§ 844.08  EXHIBITION OF LICENSE.
   Commercial solicitors are required to exhibit their licenses at the request
of any citizen.
(Ord. 2008-49, passed 9-16-2008)
§ 844.09  DUTY OF POLICE TO ENFORCE.
   It shall be the duty of any police officer of the village to require any
person seen engaging in commercial solicitation, who is not known to the
officer to be licensed, to produce his or her license and enforce this chapter
against any person found to be violating the same.
(Ord. 2008-49, passed 9-16-2008)
§ 844.10  RECORDS.
   The Chief of Police shall report to the Mayor or his or her designee all
convictions for violation of this chapter and the Mayor or his or her designee
shall maintain a record for each license issued and record the reports of the
violation therein.
(Ord. 2008-49, passed 9-16-2008)
§ 844.11  REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   (a)   Licenses issued under this chapter may be revoked by the Mayor or his
or her designee after notice and hearing for any of the following causes:
      (1)   Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the
application of license;
      (2)   Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of
carrying on his or her business as a solicitor or as canvasser;
      (3)   Any violation of this chapter;
      (4)   Conviction of any crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude;
or
      (5)   Conducting the business of commercial solicitation, in an unlawful
manner, including but not limited to trespassing, or in a manner as to
constitute a breach of the peace, or to constitute a menace to the health,
safety or general welfare of the public.
   (b)   Notice of the hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in
writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of complaint and the time and
place of hearing. The notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee
at his or her last known address at least five days prior to the date set for
hearing.
(Ord. 2008-49, passed 9-16-2008)
§ 844.12  APPEAL.
   Any person aggrieved by the action of the Chief of Police or the Mayor or
his or her designee in the denial or revocation of a permit or license shall
have the right to appeal to Village Council. The appeal shall be taken by the
filing with the higher level administrative authority, within 14 days after
notice of the action complained of has been mailed to the person's last known
address, a written statement setting forth fully the grounds for the appeal.
Village Council shall set a time and place for a hearing on the appeal and
notice of the hearing shall be given to the appellant in the same manner for
notice of hearing on revocation. The decision and order of the Village Council
on the appeal shall be final and conclusive; provided, however, that if an
appeal is perfected under this section, the effective date of revocation of any
such permit shall be stayed until the appeal has been held if the appeal is
perfected.
(Ord. 2008-49, passed 9-16-2008)
§ 844.13  EXPIRATION OF LICENSE.
   All licenses issued under this chapter shall expire 90 days following the
date of issuance, unless otherwise specified on the face of the license.
(Ord. 2008-49, passed 9-16-2008)
§ 844.14  SALES ON PUBLIC PROPERTY.
   No person shall on any public street, alley, drive, lane, thoroughfare,
public right-of-way, court, highway, and boulevard or on the sidewalks thereof,
solicit the sale of any merchandise, wares, goods, foods, periodicals or other
articles of value for present or future delivery.
(Ord. 2008-49, passed 9-16-2008)
§ 844.15  TIME RESTRICTIONS FOR COMMERCIAL SOLICITATION.
   Commercial solicitation is prohibited between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and 9:
00 a.m. each day. No commercial solicitation is permitted at any time on a
Sunday or a state or a national holiday.
(Ord. 2008-49, passed 9-16-2008)
§ 844.16  PRIVATE CITIZENS MAY PROHIBIT DOOR-TO-DOOR CANVASSING.
   (a)   Notwithstanding the provisions of any other chapter of this code, any
person, firm or corporation who is the owner or lawful occupant of private
property within the territorial limits of the village may prohibit the practice
of door-to-door canvassing by posting upon such property a sign which reads "No
Solicitation" or other similar message upon or near the main entrance door to
the residence or place of business.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any canvasser to go upon any premises and
ring the doorbell upon or near any door, rap or knock upon any door, or create
any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of any
occupant of such residence or building for the purpose of door-to-door
canvassing in defiance of the sign exhibited in accordance with division (a) of
this section, unless the canvasser has been previously invited upon the
premises by the owner, lessee, or an adult occupant thereof. This prohibition
is applicable to all persons, including those who are licensed for commercial
solicitation as described in this chapter.
   (c)   Any door-to-door canvassing conducted in violation of division (b) of
this section shall be subject to penalty under §
844.99.
(Ord. 2008-49, passed 9-16-2008)
§ 844.17  EXEMPTIONS.
   (a)   Any person soliciting contributions for or conducting door-to-door
canvassing for which the primary purpose is to solicit funds or sell goods for
the benefit of charitable or not-for-profit organizations, or for the purpose
of providing information, either written or oral, to the occupants of the
dwellings about candidates for public office, political issues or religious or
church-related matters shall not be required to obtain a license or pay a fee,
but shall register with the Police Department. The organization or person shall
provide to the Police Department, for identification purposes, his or her name,
address, and telephone number. The organization or person shall also notify the
Police Department personally of the time period and specific areas within the
village that they are canvassing. No person or organization registered as an
exemption shall canvass or solicit in an area or at a time not previously
listed with the Police Department.
   (b)   Residents of the village who engage in door-to-door canvassing for
which the primary purpose is to solicit funds or sell goods for the benefit of
charitable or not-for-profit organizations, or for the purpose of providing
information, either written or oral, to the occupants of the dwelling about
candidates for public office, political issues or religious or church-related
matters, are exempt from all requirements of this chapter except §
844.16.
(Ord. 2008-49, passed 9-16-2008)
§ 844.18  ORGANIZATIONAL LIABILITY.
   An organization may be prosecuted and held liable for the criminal penalties
contained in §
844.99(B) for any violation of this chapter committed by an officer, agent or
employee of the organization acting in its behalf and within the scope of his
or her office or employment.
(Ord. 2008-49, passed 9-16-2008)
§ 844.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter, in addition to any
penalty already provided, shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be
fined no more than $100. Each violation shall constitute a separate offense,
and each entry upon different property shall constitute a separate offense.
   (b)   An organization convicted under this chapter shall be guilty of a
minor misdemeanor and shall be fined no more than $1,000. Each violation shall
constitute a separate offense, and each entry upon different property shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 2008-49, passed 9-16-2008)
CHAPTER 846:  PUBLIC HALLS
Section
846.01   Purpose
846.02   Public hall defined
846.03   Hours of operation
846.04   Posting required
846.99   Penalty
Cross-reference:
   Live entertainment, see
Ch. 832
   Mechanical amusement devices, see
Ch. 836
Statutory reference:
   Intoxicating liquor in dance halls, see Ohio R.C. § 4399.14
   Power to regulate dancing academies and public ballrooms, see Ohio R.C. §
715.61
§ 846.01  PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to provide for reasonable regulation of the
hours of operation of public halls in order to ensure that the peace and quiet
of the village and its residents are preserved and protected.
(Ord. 82-18, passed 2-1-1982)
§ 846.02  PUBLIC HALL DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, PUBLIC HALL means any room, hall, place or space
which is rented, leased, given or used for dances, parties, entertainment or
social events, except that this definition shall not be interpreted to include
private homes used by the inhabitants of such private homes for private
functions to which no admission is charged.
(Ord. 82-18, passed 2-1-1982)
§ 846.03  HOURS OF OPERATION.
   No person shall rent, lease or permit a public hall to be used or otherwise
operate a public hall after the hour of 1:00 a.m. or prior to the hour of 6:00
a.m. This section shall not limit the right of maintenance workers, clean-up
crews or security personnel to remain on the premises for the exclusive
purposes of maintenance, clean-up or security.
(Ord. 82-18, passed 2-1-1982)
§ 846.04  POSTING REQUIRED.
   A copy of this chapter must be posted in a conspicuous place in every public
hall.
(Ord. 82-18, passed 2-1-1982)
§ 846.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than $500
for each offense.  A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during
or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.
(Ord. 82-18, passed 2-1-1982)
CHAPTER 852:  SALES FROM VEHICLES
Section
852.01   Definitions
852.02   Licenses required
852.03   License applications; fees; issuance
852.04   Sound devices
852.99   Penalty
Cross-reference:
   Conducting business from motor vehicles, see §
452.15
   Itinerant vendors, see
Ch. 824
   Soliciting business from motorists; riding on outside of vehicle, see §
416.06
Statutory reference:
   Frozen desserts, see Ohio R.C. §§ 3717.51 et seq.
   Sales of goods within right-of-way of interstate and highways, see Ohio R.C.
§ 5515.07
§ 852.01  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   PERSON.  Any individual, partnership, firm or corporation.
   VEHICLE.  Automobiles, trucks, buses, bicycles and other manually or motive-
powered machines with two or more wheels.
(Ord. 25-1980, passed 6-5-1980)
§ 852.02  LICENSES REQUIRED.
   No person shall sell or in any way dispose of ice cream, candy or other
allied products from a vehicle without first obtaining licenses therefore from
the Chief of Police for the vehicle and for the driver, and then only between
the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m.
(Ord. 25-1980, passed 6-5-1980)
§ 852.03  LICENSE APPLICATIONS; FEES; ISSUANCE.
   (a)   Applications for the licenses required by §
852.02 shall be made on forms prescribed by the Chief of Police.  The fee for
each vehicle license is $25 and the fee for each license to operate such
vehicle is $25.  Upon receipt thereof, the license for each vehicle shall be
prominently displayed on the outside of such vehicle on a place to be
determined by the Chief.
   (b)   An applicant for a license to operate such vehicle shall produce a
valid state driver’s license and a current photograph and shall be
fingerprinted.  No such license shall be issued to:
      (1)   A driver under the age of 18 years;
      (2)   A driver who has been convicted of a felony;
      (3)   A driver who has been convicted of driving under the influence of
alcohol or any drug of abuse, in any court;
      (4)   A driver who has been convicted of a misdemeanor or felony, in any
court, on morals charges or who has been found pursuant to Ohio R.C. Chapter
2950 to be a sexual predator, habitual sex offender or sexually oriented
offender; or
      (5)   A driver who has been convicted, in any court, of two or more
moving traffic violations within four years prior to making such application.
   (c)   No license shall be issued to a vehicle that has been declared, by the
Chief of Police, to be unroadworthy or inadequate for street service to
children.
(Ord. 25-1980, passed 6-5-1980; Am. Ord. 2004-30, passed 6-15-2004)
§ 852.04  SOUND DEVICES.
   No person who is selling, offering to sell or in any way disposing of ice
cream, candy or other allied products from a vehicle shall operate or cause to
be operated any device which emits an audible sound from the vehicle while it
is stopped.
(Ord. 25-1980, passed 6-5-1980)
§ 852.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than $500
for each offense.  A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during
or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.
(Ord. 25-1980, passed 6-5-1980)
CHAPTER 856:  TAXICABS AND RENTAL VEHICLES

642.04

§ 856.01  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ADMINISTRATOR.  The Village Administrator.
   AUTO-FOR-HIRE.  Any public vehicle other than a taxicab, driverless auto-
for-hire and funeral car. An AUTO-FOR-HIRE shall be driven by the owner or his
or her employee and shall not secure or accept a passenger for hire on the
public streets or on public or quasi-public places, or accept a passenger for
hire on hail or request made in a public street or on public or quasi-public
places.
   DRIVERLESS AUTO-FOR-HIRE.  Any public vehicle which is rented or hired out
to a person other than the owner and operated by the person renting or hiring
the same for his or her own use and not for the purpose of transporting persons
for compensation.
   OWNER.  As applied to a public vehicle, means the person who has good title
thereto by lawful certificate of title and who, in the conduct of his or her
business, operates or rents such public vehicle.
   PERSON. Includes a firm, partnership, association and corporation.
   PUBLIC VEHICLE.  A vehicle furnishing individual service for compensation in
the transportation of persons on public streets.  PUBLIC VEHICLES are
classified as TAXICABS, AUTOS-FOR-HIREand DRIVERLESS AUTOS-FOR-HIRE.  Vehicles
furnishing mass service, such as street railway cars, motor buses and
omnibuses, which move over fixed routes, or on a fixed schedule, or between
fixed termini, are not included in the term PUBLIC VEHICLE, but must comply
with the appropriate provisions of law and ordinances.
   RENTEE.  The person to whom a driverless auto-for-hire is rented by the
owner.
   TAXICAB.  Any public vehicle whose owner or driver secures or accepts a
passenger for hire on the public streets or on public or quasi-public places,
or accepts a passenger for hire upon hail or request made in the public streets
or on public or quasi-public places.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)
§ 856.02  OPERATOR’S LICENSE REQUIRED; FEES.
   (a)   No person or entity shall operate or permit or cause to be operated a
vehicle as a public vehicle, or proffer the services of such a vehicle as a
vehicle, by solicitation by voice, sign, public advertisement or otherwise,
unless the proper license has been issued to the owner thereof and is in force.
   (b)   Every license shall expire on January 31 of the year following the
year in which it was issued.
   (c)   License fees for any year or part thereof for each public vehicle
shall be payable to the Auditor in the following amounts per year:
 
Taxicab                  $25
Auto-for-hire            $15
Driverless auto-for-hire $10
 
   (d)   The license fee required by this section shall be in addition to any
fee required by the laws of the state.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 92-12, passed 3-16-1992)  Penalty, see §
856.99
§ 856.03  LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Applications for licenses for public vehicles shall be made to the Village
Administrator, upon blanks provided by the Administrator, and shall set forth
the name and address of the applicant, the trade name under which he or she
does business, the class of each vehicle for which a license is desired, the
seating capacity, the design, color scheme and lettering and marks to be upon
such vehicle and any other information required by the Administrator. If the
application is granted, the applicant shall furnish the Administrator, prior to
the issuance of the license tag, with information covering the particular
vehicle to be licensed, such information to include the make, the state license
number, the length of time the vehicle has been in use, the motor power
thereof, and the name and address of the person from whom or which the vehicle
was purchased, and any other information required by the Administrator
pertinent to the issuance of a license.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)
§ 856.04  ISSUANCE OF TAXICAB AND AUTO-FOR-HIRE LICENSES.
   (a)   The Village Administrator shall investigate and hold a hearing as to
each application for a taxicab or auto-for-hire operator’s license. If the
Administrator finds from such investigation and hearing that the public
convenience and necessity justify the operation of the vehicle for which the
license is desired, he or she shall forthwith notify the applicant of his or
her finding. Within 60 days thereafter, the applicant shall furnish the
Administrator with the additional information required, and if the
Administrator then finds that the applicant is the owner of the vehicle for
which the license is desired, that such vehicle is a safe and fit conveyance
and that it complies with all of the requirements of this chapter, he or she
shall notify the Village Clerk-Treasurer, who shall issue a license to the
applicant upon payment of the proper license fee and the furnishing of the bond
or insurance required. If the applicant does not comply with the requirements
of this section within 60 days, the finding of the Administrator shall be null
and void.
   (b)   If the Administrator finds from such investigation and hearing that
the public convenience and necessity do not justify the operation of the
vehicle for which the license is desired, he or she shall forthwith notify the
applicant of his or her finding.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)
§ 856.05  ISSUANCE OF DRIVERLESS AUTO-FOR-HIRE LICENSES.
   The Village Administrator shall investigate each application for a license
for a driverless auto-for-hire.  If he or she finds that the applicant is the
owner of the vehicle for which the license is desired and that such vehicle is
a safe and fit conveyance, he or she shall notify the Village Clerk-Treasurer,
who shall issue a license to the applicant upon payment of the proper license
fee and the furnishing of the bond or insurance required.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)
§ 856.06  REVOCATION OF TAXICAB AND AUTO-FOR-HIRE LICENSES.
   Whenever any person holding one or more licenses for taxicabs or autos-for-
hire fails, for a period of 60 days consecutively, to make a reasonable and
consistent effort to operate any such licensed taxicab or auto-for-hire, the
Village Administrator shall revoke the license for such vehicle or vehicles.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)
§ 856.07  PROHIBITION AGAINST NEW LICENSES.
   No new license shall be issued to a person if his or her license has been
revoked.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)
§ 856.08  LIABILITY INSURANCE OR BOND GENERALLY.
   (a)   No license to operate a public vehicle shall be issued or renewed by
the Village Clerk-Treasurer, and no person shall operate a public vehicle or
permit the same to be operated, unless and until the applicant deposits with
the Village Administrator a policy or policies of liability insurance issued by
a responsible insurance company, approved as to sufficiency by the
Administrator and as to legality by the Solicitor, providing indemnity for or
protection to the insured against loss in the amounts provided for in this
chapter.
   (b)   The policy of insurance aforesaid and the bond given in lieu thereof,
as hereinafter referred to, shall provide that if the vehicle is operated,
maintained or used with the consent or acquiescence of the owner, by one other
than the owner, his or her agent or employee, and an injury results to a person
or property as indicated above, due to the negligent operation, maintenance or
use of such vehicle, then the insurer or the obligors on the bond, as the case
may be, shall pay to any judgment creditor of such person so maintaining, using
or operating such vehicle, any final judgment rendered against such person so
maintaining, using or operating such vehicle, provided that such judgment
creditor has filed his or her suit, or filed notice of claim for such loss in
all respects, as is provided for the judgment creditor of the insured in this
section.
   (c)   The policy of insurance and the bond hereinafter required shall be
valid and effective for the same period for which the license is issued.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)
§ 856.09  INSURANCE OR BOND FOR DRIVERLESS AUTOS-FOR-HIRE.
   (a)   No license to operate a driverless auto-for-hire shall be issued or
renewed by the Village Clerk-Treasurer, and no person shall operate any such
vehicle, or permit the same to be operated, unless and until the applicant
deposits with the Village Administrator a policy or policies of liability
insurance issued by a responsible insurance company, approved as to sufficiency
by the Administrator and as to legality by the Solicitor, providing indemnity
for or protection to the rentee against loss in amounts provided for in this
chapter and agreeing to pay, within the limits of such amounts, to any
judgement creditor, any final judgment rendered against the rentee by reason of
the liability of the rentee to pay damages to others, except to occupants of
such driverless auto-for-hire, for bodily injury, including death, at any time
resulting therefrom, and for damages to or destruction of property sustained
during the term of such policy resulting from negligent operation, maintenance
or use of such driverless auto- for-hire. However, any person claiming the
protection of this section shall, within 30 days after the date of the accident
out of which the injury or damage arises, file with the Village Clerk-Treasurer
his or her claim for injury or damages together with a statement setting forth,
to the best of his or her knowledge, the day, hour and place of the accident,
the license number of the vehicle at fault, the name and address of the driver,
if known, and the name and address of witnesses of the accident to the extent
the same are known to him or her, except that where the injured person is by
the accident rendered incapable of preparing the claim and statement required
herein, such claim and statement may be filed within 30 days after such person
becomes able to prepare the same or, in the case of death resulting from the
injury, within 30 days after the date of such death.
   (b)   The policy of insurance required by this section may provide that if a
rentee is independently insured against liability, the indemnity herein
provided shall not apply except to the extent that such independent insurance
is made to furnish the protection required by this chapter. It shall further be
permissible for the owner to furnish insurance as to damages for personal
injuries, including death, and an indemnity bond as to property damages or
vice-versa.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)
§ 856.10  FAILURE TO PAY JUDGMENT AGAINST RENTEE.
   If the owner of a driverless auto-for-hire is obligated under his or her
bond, executed in accordance with this chapter, to pay a judgment recovered
against a rentee of such public vehicle and such judgment remains unsatisfied
for a period of 30 days after it becomes final, the Village Clerk- Treasurer,
upon being advised of such fact, shall forthwith revoke the driverless auto-
for-hire license or licenses held by such owner.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)
§ 856.11  SERVICE OF SUMMONS ON OWNER.
   Every rentee of a driverless auto-for-hire shall designate and constitute
the owner as his or her agent to accept service of summons for and on his or
her behalf in any action based on negligent operation, maintenance or use of
such vehicle. The owner shall agree to accept summons for and on behalf of the
rentee under such circumstances. The provisions of this section shall be
embodied in the rental contract and in the policy of insurance or bond filed by
the owner with the Village Administrator.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)
§ 856.12  EXTENT OF LIABILITY.
   The extent of the liability of the insurer or sureties shall be, as to any
one licensed public vehicle, $100,000 on account of injuries to or death of any
one person in any one accident, $200,000 on account of any one accident
resulting in injury to or death of more than one person and $50,000 on account
of damage to property in any one accident.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)
§ 856.13  BOND IN LIEU OF INSURANCE.
   In lieu of the policy or policies of insurance provided for in this chapter,
the applicant may furnish a bond executed by a surety company authorized to do
business in the state, or by two personal sureties, approved as to sufficiency
by the Village Administrator and as to legality by the Solicitor, holding and
binding the principal and sureties to the same liability and subject to the
same conditions as in the case of policies of insurance provided for herein. It
shall further be permissible for the applicant to furnish insurance as to
damages for personal injuries, including death, and an indemnity bond as to
property damages or vice-versa.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)
§ 856.14  NOTICE OF TERMINATION OF INSURANCE OR BOND.
   Every policy or certificate of insurance or bond required under this chapter
shall contain a clause obligating the insurer or surety to give to the Village
Administrator at least ten days written notice before the cancellation,
expiration, lapse or other termination of such insurance, or the expiration,
withdrawal of the surety therefrom or other termination of such bond, and the
license granted shall be suspended upon the termination of such insurance or
bond, or upon the termination of the liability of the insurer or surety
thereon, in accordance with such notice, unless and until a new policy or
certificate of liability insurance, or a new indemnity bond, approved as
hereinbefore provided, is substituted therefore. Failure to give the notice
required shall operate to continue the liability of the insurer or surety for
the benefit of persons injured or damaged, and such policy shall continue in
full force and effect.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)
§ 856.15  METAL TAGS.
   At the time the license is issued by the Village Clerk-Treasurer to the
owner of any public vehicle, such Village Clerk-Treasurer shall also issue to
such owner a metal tag showing the class of public vehicle, the license number
and the year for which issued.  The tag for each public vehicle shall be
numbered separately and the tag for each taxicab shall be numbered to
correspond to the body number assigned by the Administrator.  No tag shall be
displayed on any public vehicle except the one for which it was issued. The tag
shall be affixed to the front of the vehicle so as to be plainly discernible at
all times. Whenever the owner of a public vehicle ceases to operate the same,
or whenever the license of the public vehicle is suspended or revoked, the
owner shall return the tag to the Village Clerk-Treasurer. In the case of
reinstatement after suspension, the Village Clerk-Treasurer shall re-issue the
tag to the licensee.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)  Penalty, see §
856.99
§ 856.16  LOST TAGS.
   In case of the loss of a license tag, the owner may file with the Village
Administrator a sworn statement of the facts concerning such loss, and if the
Administrator is satisfied that the facts justify the issuance of a replacement
tag, he or she shall notify the Village Clerk-Treasurer, who shall thereupon
issue a replacement tag.  The charge for the first replacement tag for any
public vehicle shall be $1 and for each subsequent replacement tag, $2.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)
§ 856.17  LIMITATION ON USE OF PUBLIC VEHICLES.
   (a)   No driver of a public vehicle shall:
      (1)   Operate over any fixed or regular route;
      (2)   Pass any specified point on a fixed or regular time schedule for
the purpose of picking up passengers; or
      (3)   Pick up parties on the public streets or public places or solicit
patronage for a vehicle already hired.
   (b)   Nothing contained in this section shall apply where the public vehicle
is operated under a special trip rate as provided herein.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952)  Penalty, see §
856.99
§ 856.18  SIGNS AND THE LIKE ON AUTOS-FOR-HIRE; SOLICITATION OF BUSINESS; USE
OF AUTO-FOR-HIRE AS DRIVERLESS AUTO-FOR-HIRE.
   No auto-for-hire shall exhibit any sign, symbol, lettering or figure on or
from any part of such vehicle, except the license tags required by law, nor
shall the driver of any auto-for-hire solicit or accept passengers on the
streets, public places or quasi-public places, or stand in any public taxicab
stand, but an auto-for-hire may be used as a driverless auto-for-hire without
an additional license fee.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952)  Penalty, see §
856.99
§ 856.19  IDENTIFICATION, PAINTING AND LETTERING OF TAXICABS.
   (a)   Every person owning and operating a taxicab under license from the
municipality may adopt any trade name, design, color scheme or method of
painting or lettering such taxicab that is approved by the Village
Administrator.  Such trade name, design, color scheme or method of painting or
lettering shall include the following matter:
      (1)   A serial body number assigned by the Administrator to each taxicab
and painted on each side and on the rear of the taxicab; and
      (2)   The name of the owner or the trade name under which he, she or it
does business, painted on each side of the taxicab.
   (b)   Whenever the name of the owner, or the trade name under which he, she
or it does business, does not include any one of the words “Taxicab,” “Taxi” or
“Cab,” then the word “Taxicab” shall be painted on each side of the taxicab
immediately beneath such name or trade name.
   (c)   Whenever any person owning or operating a taxicab does not adopt and
use an approved trade name, design, color scheme or method of painting and
lettering as hereinbefore mentioned, then it shall be mandatory for such person
to paint the following matter on his or her taxicab:
      (1)   A frame panel, enclosing on separate lines the name of the owner,
the word “Taxicab,” and the serial body number assigned to the taxicab by the
Administrator. Such panel shall be painted on each side of the taxicab and
shall cover an area at least ten inches by 12 inches. The form of such panel
shall be substantially as follows:
   JOHN T. SMITH
   TAXICAB
   320
      (2)   The serial body number assigned the taxicab by the Administrator,
painted on the rear exterior of the taxicab.
   (d)   All mandatory lettering and wording, whether in a particular trade
name, design, color scheme, method of painting or lettering or otherwise, as
hereinbefore provided, shall be at least two inches in height and shall be of
such color as, in the opinion of the Administrator, will contrast with the
color of the body of the taxicab. The serial body numbers on the sides and rear
shall be not less than three inches in height.
   (e)   Whenever the word PAINT or PAINTED is used in this chapter, it means
the application of coloring matter in oil solution and not in water solution.
   (f)    No person shall cause or permit any taxicab to appear with a trade
name, design, color scheme or method of painting and lettering that is not
approved by the Administrator for the vehicle concerned or that is not in
accordance with this chapter.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)  Penalty, see §
856.99
§ 856.20  ADVERTISING AND SIGNS ON TAXICABS.
   No taxicab shall carry lettering, signs or advertisements on or in any
window or windshield except as approved by the Village Administrator.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)  Penalty, see §
856.99
§ 856.21  FARES FOR TAXICABS.
   (a)   (1)   No fare or charge for the use of a taxicab for one trip from
place to place within the municipality shall exceed $0.50.
      (2)   If and when a passenger, in addition to the passenger engaging the
taxicab, requests a stop within three municipal blocks from the direct route, a
charge of not more than $0.35 may be made for each such stop.
   (b)   If a stop for waiting is requested by any passenger, a charge of not
more than $0.25 may be made for each such waiting.
   (c)   When the number of persons desiring taxicabs is in excess of the
taxicabs available, any person desiring transportation in the same general
direction may thereupon enter the same taxicab as other passengers.  The
regular single trip fare may be charged each passenger.
(Ord. 1367, passed 1-11-1960)  Penalty, see §
856.99
§ 856.22  FARES FOR AUTOS-FOR-HIRE.
   (a)   Fares and charges for the use of an auto-for-hire shall not exceed the
following:
      (1)   For a car seating five passengers or less, $4 per hour,
irrespective of the number of persons carried; and
      (2)   For a car seating six passengers or more, $5 per hour, irrespective
of the number of persons carried.
   (b)   The time for which a charge may be made shall not include the time
taken to reach the passenger or, after dismissal, to reach the station of the
licensee. No passenger shall be carried for less than a one-half hour charge.
   (c)   No driver or other person in control of a taxicab or auto-for-hire
shall make any charge except in accordance with the schedule of rates herein
provided.
   (d)   Whenever a new schedule of rates becomes effective or whenever an
auto-for-hire or taxicab license is transferred from owner to owner or from
vehicle to vehicle, or whenever any of the information on the rate card becomes
incorrect, the Village Administrator shall require a new or correct rate card.
   (e)   No person shall alter or tamper with a rate card. Whenever a rate card
becomes damaged, soiled or illegible, the owner shall provide and the
Administrator shall approve a new card for the vehicle when it is deemed
satisfactory by the Administrator.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)  Penalty, see §
856.99
§ 856.23  RATE RECEIPTS.
   The driver of a taxicab or auto-for-hire shall, if requested, deliver to the
person paying for the hire of the same, at the time of payment, a receipt
therefore.  Upon this receipt shall be legibly printed or written the name of
the owner, a method of identifying the vehicle or its driver, all items for
which charge is made, the total amount paid and the date of payment.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952)  Penalty, see §
856.99
§ 856.24  BAGGAGE AND CHILDREN.
   No charge shall be made for any bag, suitcase or ordinary light traveling
baggage, not heavier than 50 pounds, carried by any person paying a fare, nor
for children under four years of age when accompanied by a person paying a
fare, provided that not more than two such children shall be carried free. If
more than two such children accompanied by a person paying a fare are carried,
the rate of fare chargeable for additional passengers shall apply to all
children in excess of two. For children under four years of age not accompanied
by an adult paying a fare, and for all children over four years of age, all
provisions as to fare for individual and additional passengers shall apply.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952)  Penalty, see §
856.99
§ 856.25  ARTICLES LEFT IN VEHICLES.
   Drivers of public vehicles shall promptly deliver to the Police Department,
or the authorized agencies of their companies, all property of value left in
such vehicles by passengers.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952)
§ 856.26  RECORDS.
   The owner or person in charge of one or more taxicabs or autos-for-hire
shall keep a record of all such vehicles, showing the body number, the
municipal license number, the state license number and such data as may be
necessary to identify the driver of such vehicle or vehicles at any and all
times. Such owner or person in charge shall also keep a record of the time of
departure from and arrival at his or her garage or the headquarters of such
taxicab or auto-for-hire. All taxicab and auto-for-hire drivers shall make
records which shall be preserved by the owner or person in charge, showing the
time of beginning and the time of ending of each trip, the first and last stop
and the amount of fare collected. The records shall be subject to inspection at
all times by the Police Department and by the Village Administrator and shall
not be destroyed for a period of six months.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)  Penalty, see §
856.99
§ 856.27  TRANSFER OF LICENSES, VEHICLE TO VEHICLE.
   If the owner of a licensed public vehicle ceases to own the same, or if such
vehicle becomes unsuitable for operation or the owner desires to substitute
another vehicle, an affidavit to such effect may be filed with the Village
Administrator and the Administrator shall thereupon notify the Village Clerk-
Treasurer, who shall transfer the license to any other vehicle belonging to
such owner, provided such vehicle is of the same class and approved by the
Administrator.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)
§ 856.28  TRANSFER OF LICENSES, OWNER TO OWNER.
   No public vehicle license shall be transferred from one owner to another by
the Village Clerk- Treasurer except after a finding of public convenience and
necessity by the Village Administrator. Such finding shall be arrived at in the
same manner as in the case of an original application.  The applicant for the
transfer of a license shall file with his or her application the consent, in
writing, of the former owner of such license and shall comply with all of the
provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)  Penalty, see §
856.99
§ 856.29  DRIVER’S PERMITS.
   (a)   No person shall drive a taxicab, livery or auto-for-hire as a driver
in the municipality without first obtaining a taxicab driver’s permit from the
municipality.  The permits shall expire annually on January 31 in the year
following the year in which it was issued, and further provided that all
taxicab driver permits in existence as of the date on which this provision was
adopted shall expire on January 31, 1993.
   (b)   The Village Administrator or the Chief of Police is hereby authorized
to issue a permit if, after a complete investigation of past arrests and
convictions of the applicant for traffic violations, acts of violence in which
the applicant was convicted and his or her record of arrests and convictions
for felonies, it appears that the record is not one of any consequence. If,
however, the record is such that, in the opinion of the Administrator or the
Chief of Police, the public interest will be better protected by denying the
application, then such may be denied.
   (c)   A person issued such a permit shall supply to the municipality two
small photographs of himself or herself taken within one year of the
application for the permit.  One shall be attached to the permit and displayed
in the vehicle operated, visible at all times.  The second shall remain on file
at the Police Department.
   (d)   The fee for permits shall be $5 and at all times shall remain the
property of the municipality.
   (e)   The permit must be surrendered to the Administrator or the Chief of
Police on demand when reasonable cause is given for the removal of the same.
(Ord. 1567, passed 4-9-1973; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982; Am. Ord. 92-12,
passed 3-16-1992)  Penalty, see §
856.99
§ 856.30  PRIVATE CARRYING OF PASSENGERS FOR HIRE.
   The acceptance of passengers or the offer to accept passengers for
compensation by the operator of any vehicle other than a public vehicle, duly
licensed under and operating in accordance with the provisions of the
ordinances of the municipality, or by other than motor buses, omnibuses or
streetcars, operating under proper authority, is hereby prohibited.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952)  Penalty, see §
856.99
§ 856.31  PUBLIC VEHICLES FROM OTHER MUNICIPALITIES.
   The operator of a public vehicle, duly licensed under other proper
authority, but having no municipal license, the place of business of the owner
of which is not in the municipality, may bring passengers into the
municipality, but may not accept any passengers, or offer to accept any
passengers, for compensation, or accept any business whatsoever within the
municipality for any destination in the county.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952)  Penalty, see §
856.99
§ 856.32  MOTOR VEHICLES RESEMBLING PUBLIC VEHICLES.
   No person shall equip, mark, paint or in any other way cause any motor
vehicle to resemble a duly licensed public vehicle or create a public
impression that a motor vehicle is a duly licensed public vehicle approved by
the Village Administrator under authority of this chapter.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)  Penalty, see §
856.99
§ 856.33  FAILURE TO PAY FARE.
   No person, with intent to defraud the owner or driver of any public vehicle,
shall engage carriage therein. Refusal to pay the lawful charge for such
carriage or absconding without payment or offer to pay is evidence of such
intent to defraud.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952)  Penalty, see §
856.99
§ 856.34  PUBLIC VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   Every public vehicle shall be kept in a safe and sanitary operating
condition and shall at all times have the following equipment:
      (1)   A light within the passenger compartment, capable of being lighted
or extinguished by the passenger;
      (2)   A spare tire, capable of being used on any of the wheels of the
vehicle;
      (3)   A set of tools for changing tires;
      (4)   Brakes sufficient to control the vehicle at all times, and no
brakes shall be deemed to comply with the requirements of this section unless
they are capable of stopping the vehicle within 25 feet from a speed of 20
miles per hour on a hard, dry, level road free of loose material. In addition,
every public vehicle shall have an emergency brake capable of holding such
vehicle on any grade that it can ascend.
      (5)   Skid chains, to be applied to the rear wheels when their use is
desirable to promote safety.
   (b)   Whenever a public vehicle is found not to be in a safe and sanitary
operating condition or not to comply fully with all the requirements specified
herein, the Village Administrator shall suspend or revoke the license of the
vehicle concerned until this section is complied with.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)  Penalty, see §
856.99
§ 856.35  USE OF VEHICLES FOR UNLAWFUL OR IMMORAL PURPOSES.
   No person shall use a public vehicle for an unlawful or immoral purpose.
When such unlawful or immoral use occurs with the knowledge of the person
owning or driving the public vehicle, the Village Administrator, after a
hearing, may revoke the vehicle license for the vehicle involved.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)  Penalty, see §
856.99
§ 856.36  TAXICAB CRUISING.
   No person shall drive a taxicab through the streets without passengers, in
such a manner that one point is passed more than once within ten minutes or,
with or without passengers, in such a manner as to impede or interfere with
traffic.
(Ord. 1094, passed 4-11-1949)  Penalty, see §
856.99
§ 856.37  TAXICAB STANDS.
   The Village Administrator is hereby authorized and directed to establish
such taxicab stands as will serve the best interests of the public and such
authority and direction shall include the establishment of taxicab stands in
front of fire hydrants as the need of the public may require. Such taxicab
stands shall be designated by a sign or signs indicating that they are taxicab
stands. Such stands shall be reserved exclusively for the parking of taxicabs
while awaiting passengers for hire. The driver of a taxicab shall remain in or
beside his or her taxicab when parked in a taxicab stand. The driver of a
taxicab which is engaged shall not occupy a place in a taxicab stand with such
vehicle. Except in authorized taxicab stands, no person shall park a taxicab
upon a public street or alley within a congested district. No person shall park
a taxicab in a taxicab stand continuously for a period exceeding one hour.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)  Penalty, see §
856.99
§ 856.38  MAXIMUM NUMBER OF PASSENGERS; USE OF FRONT SEAT.
   No public vehicle shall carry more passengers than the number designated as
the seating capacity in the application on which the license was issued. No
driver of a taxicab or auto-for-hire shall permit any passenger to occupy the
front seat unless the vehicle is carrying more than two persons.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952)  Penalty, see §
856.99
§ 856.39  RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Village Administrator is hereby authorized to establish and adopt such
rules and regulations governing the issuance of public vehicle licenses and the
inspection of public vehicles and their appurtenances as are reasonable and
necessary and not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)
§ 856.40  REVOCATION OF LICENSES OBTAINED BY MISREPRESENTATION.
   Whenever it appears, upon investigation and hearing by the Village
Administrator, that a license issued under this chapter was obtained by
misrepresentation, the Administrator shall notify the Village Clerk-Treasurer
of such fact and the Village Clerk-Treasurer shall thereupon revoke the
license.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)
§ 856.41  REVOCATION OF AUTO-FOR-HIRE LICENSES.
   Whenever an owner of an auto-for-hire is convicted of allowing such vehicle
to stand on any space designated by the Village Administrator, as a public
stand for taxicabs, or of soliciting or accepting passengers on the public
streets, or of displaying any sign, symbol, lettering or advertisement on the
outside of such vehicle, or of violating §
856.17, the Administrator shall notify the Village Clerk-Treasurer of such fact
and the latter shall thereupon revoke the license of such vehicle.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)
§ 856.42  REVOCATION AFTER REPEATED CONVICTIONS.
   The owner of a public vehicle shall be responsible for the lawful operation
of the same when driven by anyone with his or her knowledge.  Whenever the
driver of a public vehicle is convicted of a violation of any provision of this
chapter, the Village Administrator shall notify the owner thereof of such
conviction in writing. When convictions for violations of this chapter or of
any traffic law or ordinance have been obtained twice within 90 days, the
Administrator shall hold a public hearing as to the revocation of the license
of such vehicle. The owner shall have due notice of such public hearing. If,
after such hearing, the Administrator finds that a practice exists as to the
unlawful operation of such public vehicle, he or she shall thereupon revoke the
license for the operation thereof.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)
§ 856.43  IMPOUNDING PUBLIC VEHICLES.
   Any vehicle being operated in violation of any of the provisions of this
chapter may be impounded by the police.  A service charge of $5 shall be paid
to the municipality before the vehicle is released from the pound.  The payment
of such service charge shall not release the owner or driver of such vehicle
from the penalty imposed for violations of provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952)
§ 856.44  REVOCATION OF LICENSES OF LICENSEES OPERATING UNLICENSED VEHICLES.
   If the Village Administrator finds, after public hearing, that any licensee
of a public vehicle or vehicles has, within six months prior to such hearing,
knowingly operated or caused or permitted to be operated for compensation any
other public vehicle without a license, the Administrator may revoke any or all
of the public vehicle licenses which such licensee holds.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)
§ 856.45  APPEALS.
   Whenever the Village Administrator has refused to authorize a public vehicle
license, or whenever he or she has suspended or revoked a public vehicle
license, the applicant, within ten days after receiving notice of such denial,
suspension or revocation, may appeal to the Mayor. The Mayor may either
consider such appeal on the evidence produced before the Administrator, or
permit the introduction of new evidence, inspections and tests. The decision of
the Mayor shall be final. However, when the Administrator’s refusal of a
license is upon the grounds of public necessity and convenience, then the
applicant, within ten days after receiving notice of such refusal, may appeal
to Council. Council may either consider such appeal on the evidence produced
before the Administrator, or permit the introduction of new evidence,
inspections and tests. The decision of Council shall be final.
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)
§ 856.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than $500
for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during
or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues. 
   (b)   Upon a second or subsequent conviction, within one year of a first
conviction, of any person for operating, permitting to be operated or offering
to operate a vehicle in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, the
Mayor shall prohibit such person from operating or driving a public vehicle in
the municipality for a period of not more than one year, in addition to the
penalty provided in division (a).
   (c)   Whoever operates, permits to be operated or offers to operate a
vehicle as a public vehicle without first having obtained the appropriate
license therefore shall not, after conviction therefore, be granted a license
for the vehicle concerned for a period of three months for a first conviction
and one year for a subsequent conviction, in addition to the penalty provided
in division (a).
(Ord. 1184, passed 1-28-1952)

CHAPTER 880:  ADMISSIONS TAX
Section
880.01   Definitions
880.02   Imposition of tax
880.03   Exemptions
880.04   Returns; payment; records
880.05   License required; application; fee
880.06   Violations

   Tax Commissioner, see §§
254.01,

882.15
   Tax Department, see
Ch. 254
§ 880.01  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ADMISSION.  Seats, chairs, tables and benches and other similar
accommodations and charges made therefore.
   AMOUNTS RECEIVED FOR ADMISSION.  Does not include any federal taxes paid or
received with reference to such admission.
   PERSON.  Includes individuals, firms, partnerships, associations,
corporations and municipalities and other political subdivisions of the state.
(Ord. 1042, passed 3-22-1948)
§ 880.02  IMPOSITION OF TAX.
   For the purpose of providing revenue to defray a portion of current expenses
and other expenditures of the village, there is hereby levied a tax of three
percent on the amounts received for admission to any place, including admission
by season tickets or subscriptions.  If a person is admitted free or at a
reduced rate to any place at a time when, and in circumstances under which, an
admission charge is made to other persons, an equivalent tax shall be collected
based on the price so charged to such other persons for the same or similar
accommodations.  Such equivalent tax shall be paid by the person so admitted. 
(Ord. 1042, passed 3-22-1948)
§ 880.03  EXEMPTIONS.
   No tax shall be levied under this chapter with respect to admissions all the
proceeds of which inure exclusively to the benefit of religious, educational,
charitable, civic or veterans’ organizations or auxiliary units to veterans’
organizations or the Police or Fire Department of the municipality, provided
that no part of the net earnings thereof inures to the benefit of any private
stockholder or person.
(Ord. 1042, passed 3-22-1948)
§ 880.04  RETURNS; PAYMENT; RECORDS.
   (a)   Any person receiving a payment for admission, dues or fees taxable
under this chapter shall, on or before the fifteenth day of each calendar
month, make a return, in duplicate, under oath, to the Village Clerk-Treasurer
on such a form as the Village Clerk-Treasurer may prescribe. Such return shall
show the number of taxable admissions issued or disposed of and/or the amount
of taxable dues and/or fees collected during the preceding calendar month, the
amount of tax imposed on the same and such other facts and information as the
Village Clerk-Treasurer may require in the form of a return. One copy of such
return shall be for the use of the Village Clerk-Treasurer. Each person making
such a return shall, at the time of making the same, pay the amount of taxes
shown to be due thereon to the Village Clerk-Treasurer. Such moneys shall be
paid into the Village Treasury to the credit of the general fund.
   (b)   If the tax is not paid when due, there shall be added, as a part of
the tax, interest at the rate of one percent a month, from the time the tax
became due until paid, together with a penalty of ten percent of the amount of
the tax, unless such penalty is waived for good cause shown.
   (c)   Each person required by this chapter to collect and pay the tax
imposed hereby shall keep records of receipts, issuance of complimentary
tickets and otherwise, together with ticket stubs and other pertinent
documents, in such a form as the Village Clerk-Treasurer may, by regulation,
require. Such records and other documents shall be open at any time during
business hours to the inspection of the Village Clerk-Treasurer.
(Ord. 1042, passed 3-22-1948; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)
§ 880.05  LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION; FEE.
   No person shall conduct any form of amusement at any permanent or temporary
place, or any itinerant form of amusement, within the municipality, without
first obtaining a license therefore.  Such licenses shall be obtained from the
Mayor by application on forms prescribed by him or her, unless the person is
already the holder of some form of permanent municipal amusement license, in
which case such permanent license shall be sufficient.  Each license shall
expire on the date stated therein. The fee for such a license shall be $1.
(Ord. 1042, passed 3-22-1948)  Penalty, see §
880.99
§ 880.06  VIOLATIONS.
   No person shall conduct any form of amusement at any permanent or temporary
place, or any itinerant form of amusement, without having a license therefore,
as provided in this chapter, or, being a person charged by any section of this
chapter with the duty of collecting or paying the taxes imposed by this
chapter, willfully fail or refuse to charge and collect or pay such taxes, or
to make a return to the Village Clerk-Treasurer as required by this chapter, or
to permit the Village Clerk-Treasurer or his or her duly authorized agent to
examine his or her books and other records, in or upon any premises where the
same are kept, to the extent necessary to verify any returns made or to
ascertain and assess the tax imposed by this chapter if no return was made, or
to maintain and keep records, ticket stubs and other documents pertaining to
the sale or other disposition of admissions, as may be required by the Village
Clerk-Treasurer.
(Ord, 1042, passed 3-22-1948; Am. Ord. 82-3, passed 1-4-1982)  Penalty, see §
880.99
§ 880.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than $500
for each offense.  A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during
or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.
