§ 1040.01  SERVICE CHARGES.
   (a)   Each water supply service shall be subject to a service charge for the
maintenance of the system and use of the water. The service charge shall be
based on the size of the water meter. This section shall apply to each water
meter available for water service, but shall not apply to water supply services
subject to §
1040.08. For the availability of water service and usage of up to 650 cubic
feet of water, the service charge shall be as follows:
 
Meter Size Usage Minimum Billing
5/8 inch   0-650 cu. ft. $28.94
3/4 inch   0-650 cu. ft. $37.74
1 inch     0-650 cu. ft. $45.42
1-1/2 inch 0-650 cu. ft. $59.14
2 inch     0-650 cu. ft. $78.36
3 inch     0-650 cu. ft. $122.41
4 inch     0-650 cu. ft. $168.98
6 inch     0-650 cu. ft. $367.62
 
   (b)   For all bimonthly consumption in excess of 650 cubic feet, the charge
shall be $4.0376 per 100 cubic feet as of January 1, 2019.
   (c)   Bills for the above charges will be mailed bimonthly, to the owners of
the premises served.
   (d)   The foregoing charges are minimum charges, not maximum charges, and
the municipality reserves the right to increase the same at any time should
revenue of the waterworks system prove insufficient to pay the operating and
maintenance expenses and the debt charges of and for the system.
(Ord. 82-98, passed 12-6-1982; Am. Ord. 95-1, passed 1-17-1995; Am. Ord. 00-42,
passed 12-19-2000; Am. Ord. 2003-15, passed 5-20- 2003; Am. Ord. 2006-08,
passed 2-23-2006; Am. Ord. 2011-35, passed 5-17-2011; Am. Ord. 2015- 38, passed
12-15-2015; Am. Ord. 2019-44, passed 11-18-2019)
§ 1040.02  INVOLUNTARY TERMINATION AND REINSTATEMENT OF SERVICE.
   (a)   All water meters for premises served by the municipal waterworks
system shall be registered in the name of the owner of such premises, who shall
be billed for and who shall be liable for the payment of the charges provided
in §
1040.01.  If such bill remains unpaid for 30 days, the Village Administrator is
hereby authorized to terminate such service in accordance with the provisions
of this section.
   (b)   The Village Administrator shall not discontinue water service for
nonpayment of a water bill without giving the customer in default, whether such
customer is a landlord, owner or other person, at least seven calendar days
prior written notice thereof.  Any notice required by this section shall
include the provisions of divisions (f) and (g).
   (c)   At least seven calendar days before discontinuing water service to any
user not responsible for the payment of charges for water service, the Village
Administrator shall post, conspicuously upon the premises served, notice of
intent to terminate water service, the termination date and the rights and
obligations set forth in divisions (f) and (g).
   (d)    For purposes of this section, USER NOT RESPONSIBLE FOR THE PAYMENT OF
CHARGES FOR WATER SERVICE means any occupant of the premises served who is not
a member of the household of the customer in default, in the case of
residential customers, or any occupant who is not an agent or employee of the
customer responsible, in the case of commercial establishments.
   (e)   When premises are occupied by a single family or a single commercial
establishment and the bill has been directed to such premises, it shall be
presumed that the occupant is the user responsible for payment.
   (f)     Any such customer responsible for the payment of charges for water
service, who causes the discontinuance of that service by failure or refusal to
pay the charges for past service or who willfully causes service to be
disconnected, except while repairs are in progress or during temporary
emergencies, shall be liable for compensatory damages to any tenant who is
denied benefits of water service so disconnected.
   (g)     If a tenant makes a payment to the municipal waterworks in full
satisfaction of the arrearage of the customer who is in default in order to
avoid discontinuance of water service for nonpayment, the tenant shall have the
right to deduct the amount of such payment from any future payment of rent owed
to such customer.
   (h)   When collection of a water bill requires the posting of a notice on
the premises as provided in division (c), there shall be a charge of $25 to the
customer responsible for payment of the bill.  This charge shall be in addition
to the delinquent charge specified in §
1040.03(b).
   (i)     In the event of termination of service for nonpayment, such service
shall not be reinstated until such bill, and any additionally authorized
charges, have been paid in full.
(Ord. 88-9, passed 4-4-1988; Am. Ord. 00-42, passed 12-19-2000; Am. Ord. 2003-
15, passed 5-20-2003)
§ 1040.03  GENERAL REGULATIONS.
   (a)   Authorized representatives of the municipality may enter any premises
for the purpose of reading or inspecting the water meter only. Any refusal to
allow a representative of the municipality to read and inspect the water meter
is sufficient grounds to discontinue the water service.
   (b)   All water bills, which shall also include the charges for sewer and
garbage service, are due and payable at the end of the bimonthly period. Any
delinquent water bill, including the amounts owed for sewer and garbage, is
subject to a penalty of ten percent of the bill, compounded monthly.
   (c)   Water service that is shut off for nonpayment of a bill shall not be
turned on again until a charge of $75 is paid to the municipality in addition
to the full payment of the delinquent bill at any time turn on service is
requested.
   (d)   Whenever a street cut is made for the purpose of installing a water
main or service, a deposit of $500 shall be posted with the Village
Administrator before a cut or opening is made within the public right-of-way. 
The full amount of the deposit shall be returned upon satisfactory completion
of the street restoration.
   (e)   New water service piping of two inches or less in diameter shall be of
approved copper tubing.
   (f)   Water meters installed outside of a building shall be placed in an
approved ford meter box or in an approved meter pit.
   (g)   Water meters shall be purchased by the customer from the municipality.
All new and replacement meters shall be equipped with a pulsator so that the
meter can be read without entering the premises.  No person shall install a
water meter without an inspection by the Water Department.
   (h)   The property owner shall maintain and repair the water service from
the curb box to the property served, including, if applicable, the meter box or
pit.
   (i)   The property owner shall install water service to any property.
   (j)   All plumbing work or water line work shall be done by a licensed
plumber who has posted the proper bond with the municipality.
   (k)   No person shall tap, repair or work on a water main in the
municipality without the written permission of the Village Administrator.
   (l)     The property owner is responsible for the maintenance, repair and
replacement of water meters.  However, minor maintenance that can be
satisfactorily performed by the Water Department may be so done at no cost to
the property owner.
   (m)   If the village decides to replace a worn out or antiquated water
meter, in the absence of negligence or wrongful conduct on the part of the
property owner, there will be no charge for the replacement of a five-eighths
inch water meter on owner-occupied single-family residential premises.  The
replacement meter shall remain the property of the village.
   (n)   Any property owner or other person who is required by law to have a
standby water system for fire protection shall be charged a bimonthly fee of
$60 for the system and its service thereof.
(Ord. 88-9, passed 4-4-1988; Am. Ord. 96-22, passed 4-16-1996; Am. Ord. 00-42,
passed 12-19-2000; Am. Ord. 2003-15, passed 5-20-2003; Am. Ord. 2004-9, passed
3-16-2004; Am. Ord. 2007-09, passed 3-1-2007)  Penalty, see §
1040.99
§ 1040.04  TAP-IN FEES.
   (a)     Any property owner or other person who desires to tap into the
village water system shall make a request, in writing, to the Water
Department.  No tap shall be made without the written permission of the Village
Administrator, as required by §
1040.03(k).
   (b)     Prior to the commencement of work to tap into the water system, the
Water Department shall inspect the site and materials proposed to be used. 
After the tap-in has been completed, but before the ground is covered and the
tap-in is enclosed, the Department shall again inspect the connection.
   (c)   A tap-in fee shall be charged to users for the privilege of tapping
into the water system.  Such fee shall be paid in full at the time the written
request to tap into the water system is made.
   (d)   (1)
 
Meter Size (in inches) Tap-in Fee
5/8   $500
3/4   900
1     1,000
1-1/2 1,500
2     2,000
3     3,000
4     4,000
5     5,000
6     6,000
8     8,000
 
      (2)   However, if a water customer wishes to re-tap the main in an effort
to improve water volume and retaps the main with the same size tap and abandons
(eliminates) the old tap, a fee of $200 shall be charged.  If a reinspection of
tap is required, an additional charge of $75 shall be assessed, per inspection.
   (e)   The plumbing work for the tap shall be done by a licensed plumber who
has posted the proper bond with the municipality as required by §
1040.03(j). A deposit of $500 shall be posted before a street cut is made
within the public right-of-way, as required by §
1040.03(d).
   (f)   The property owner, at his or her own expense, shall install water
service to any property.
(Ord. 88-9, passed 4-4-1988; Am. Ord. 98-31, passed 8-18-1998; Am. Ord. 2004-9,
passed 3-16-2004)  Penalty, see §
1040.99
§ 1040.05  BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICES.
   (a)   If, in the judgment of the Village Administrator, an approved backflow
prevention device is necessary for the safety of the public water system, the
Village Administrator will give notice to the water consumer to install such an
approved device immediately.  The water consumer shall, at his or her own
expense, install such an approved device at a location and in a manner approved
by the Village Administrator and shall have inspections and tests made of such
approved device as required by the Village Administrator.
   (b)   No person shall establish or maintain, or permit to be established or
maintained, any connection whereby a private, auxiliary or emergency water
supply, other than the regular public water supply of the village, may enter
the supply or distribution system of the municipality, unless such private,
auxiliary or emergency water supply and the method of connection and use of
such supply has been approved by the Village Administrator and by the Ohio
Environmental Protection Agency.
   (c)   The Village Administrator shall cause surveys and investigations to be
made of industrial and other properties served by the public water supply where
actual or potential hazards to the public water supply may exist. Such surveys
and investigations shall be made a matter of public record and shall be
required as often as the Village Administrator deems necessary.
   (d)   The Village Administrator or his or her duly authorized representative
may enter, at any reasonable time, any property served by a connection to the
public water supply or distribution system of the village for the purpose of
inspecting the piping system thereof.  On demand, the owner, lessee or occupant
of any property so served shall furnish to the Village Administrator any
information which he or she may request regarding the piping system or water
use on such property. The refusal to furnish such information, when demanded,
shall, within the discretion of the Village Administrator, be deemed evidence
of the presence of improper connections as provided in this section.
   (e)   The Village Administrator is hereby authorized and directed to
discontinue, after reasonable notice to the occupant thereof, the water service
to any property wherein any connection in violation of this section is known to
exist, and to take such other precautionary measures as he or she may deem
necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water supply
distribution mains. Water service to such property shall not be restored until
such conditions have been eliminated or corrected in compliance with this
section.
   (f)   The Village Administrator is hereby authorized and directed to adopt
regulations consistent with and in furtherance of the purposes of this section
to provide an effective means for  protecting the public water system of the
village from contamination due to the backflow of contaminants through the
water service connection into the public water system. The regulations to be
adopted by the Village Administrator shall be substantially in accordance with
the suggested regulations on cross connection control set forth in Appendix IV
to Backflow Prevention and Cross Connection Control Third Edition, revised
1990, published by the Ohio EPA Office of Public Water Supply.
(Ord. 84-38, passed 9-4-1984)  Penalty, see §
1040.99
§ 1040.06  OWNER’S RESPONSIBILITY.
   The maintenance of water service connections being a substantial and
valuable benefit to land, any owner of real estate premises maintaining such
water service connections shall assume responsibility for the total of all
water charges levied against the premises during such ownership in the same
manner as the person who actually incurred the charges.  This assumption of
responsibility shall be a necessary condition to the continuance of water
service to the premises, and the failure to pay such charges when billed in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter shall constitute grounds for the
Village Administrator to refuse water service to the premises. 
(Ord. 88-9, passed 4-4-1988)
§ 1040.07  COLLECTION OF DELINQUENT PAYMENTS FOR WATER CHARGES.
   (a)     When water charges assessed pursuant to §
1040.01, penalties assessed pursuant to §
1040.03 or other charges related to water service are not paid and become due,
the Village Administrator may certify the delinquent amounts, plus any
penalties, to the County Auditor, who shall place a certified amount on the
real property tax list and duplicate against the property served by the
connection.
   (b)     Upon receipt of the delinquent tax list from the Village
Administrator, the County Auditor shall compile a list of individuals who have
not paid their tax indebtedness and publish the list in a newspaper of general
circulation.
   (c)     The County Auditor shall also prepare a separate list of names of
persons whose unpaid obligations exceed $100 and shall deliver the list to the
office of the County Recorder for filing on December 1 of each year.
   (d)     Unless the Village Administrator determines that the encumbered
property is about to be sold or transferred, the Administrator may only make a
certification if the rents have been due and unpaid for at least 60 days and
the Administrator has provided the responsible party with written notice of the
impending certification at least 30 days prior to the certification.
   (e)     The amount certified shall be a lien on the owner’s property from
the date placed on the list and duplicate and shall be collected in the same
manner as other taxes.
(Ord. 88-9, passed 4-4-1988)
§ 1040.08  CONNECTION TO WATER SUPPLY OTHER THAN REGULAR CITY WATER SUPPLY
PROHIBITED AND REGULATING THE INSTALLATION OF NEW WATER WELLS.
   (a)   No person, firm or corporation shall establish or permit to be
established or maintained or permit to be maintained any connection whereby a
private, auxiliary or emergency water supply other than the regular public
water supply of the Village of Lockland may enter the supply or the
distribution system of the village, unless such private, auxiliary or emergency
water supply and the method of connection and use of such supply shall have
been approved by the Director of Lockland Water System and the Ohio
Environmental Protection Agency.
   (b)   No new water wells may be drilled within the village either for
potable or non-potable water use without the express permit of the Ohio EPA and
the village through its Director of the Lockland Water System.
(Ord. 2019-27, passed 7-15-2019)
§ 1040.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than $500
for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during
or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.

§ 1042.01  PAYMENT OF CHARGES.
   Sewerage service charges established by the Metropolitan Sewer District of
Greater Cincinnati are payable at the office of the Village Administrator at
the same time as the water bills for the lot, parcel of land, building, or
premises are payable. Payments for water shall not be accepted unless payment
for the sewerage service charges is made at the same time. Any delinquent water
bill, including the amounts owed for sewerage service charges, is subject to a
penalty of ten percent of the bill, compounded monthly.

§ 1042.02  DISPOSITION OF COLLECTION FEE.
   The seven percent collection fee retained by the village from the collection
of sewer rentals and kept in the sewer fund shall be transferred to the general
fund to cover the management costs of the collection of sewer rentals.
(Res. 84-R-16, passed 11-5-1984; Am. Ord. 2005-51, passed 11-15-2005)

§ 1060.01  WASTE DISPOSAL DEFINED.
   For the purpose of this
Chapter 1060, WASTE DISPOSAL , DISPOSAL , or DISPOSE shall mean the discharge,
deposit, dumping, spilling, leaking, emitting or placing of any waste material
on any land, except if the disposition or placement constitutes temporary
storage or treatment. Disposal shall not mean injection into land by well or
otherwise, which shall be prohibited on any land in the village.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, disposal of waste into a residential septic
system, as that term is defined in OAC 1301:7-9-02(B)(54), shall be permitted.
(Ord. 2013-38, passed 5-21-2013)
§ 1060.02  GARBAGE AND TRASH CANS.
   (a)   All five-unit or more multi-family or single room occupancy
properties, hotels, stores, restaurants, or other places of business shall have
containers that are water tight with closely fitting covers for the handling of
both garbage, which is defined as refuse of animal, fish or vegetable matter
that has been used for food for man or intended to be so used, and trash,
including ashes, cinders, and waste material. If such containers have been
approved for use by the Village Administrator, the village may contract for the
disposal of garbage and trash.
   (b)   No occupant of a dwelling house or other building of up to four
dwelling units shall fail to maintain on his or her premises suitable garbage
cans, which shall be water tight with closely fitting covers and proper handles
for carrying, and which, unless in a can supplied through the village or
specifically approve by the Village Administrator, shall not exceed 35 gallons
in capacity. The cans shall be suitable for handling both garbage and trash.
The village assumes no responsibility for damage or loss of any container.
   (c)   Plastic bags or plastic can liners may be used if placed in approved
cans but must be properly tied at the opening. Plastic bags shall not be
overloaded, nor shall sharp objects be placed in plastic bags. Cardboard boxes
should not be used as waste containers. Containers either defective or not in
compliance with this chapter may be taken out of service by the village.
   (d)   No occupant referred to in this section shall fail to set the can in a
convenient place for collection, as designated by the Village Administrator,
and no occupant shall fail to keep and maintain the same in such a manner that
such cans and their contents do not become a nuisance to the neighborhood or a
safety hazard to village employees.
(Ord. 88-32, passed 11-21-1988; Am. Ord. 94-14, passed 3-7-1994; Am. Ord. 2005-
41, passed 8-18-2005; Am. Ord. 2010-67, passed 11-16-2010; Am. Ord. 2013-15,
passed 2-25-2013)  Penalty, see §
1060.99
§ 1060.03  FREQUENCY OF COLLECTION.
   All dwellings shall be serviced once a week on regularly scheduled days. In
weeks in which the following holidays occur, pick up may be one day late:
   (a)   New Year’s Day;
   (b)   Memorial Day;
   (c)   Independence Day;
   (d)   Labor Day;
   (e)   Christmas Eve;
   (f)   Christmas Day; and
   (g)   New Year’s Eve.
(Ord. 88-32, passed 11-21-1988; Am. Ord. 94-14, passed 3-7-1994)
§ 1060.04  DEFECTIVE CONTAINERS.
   Any garbage or trash can, or any receptacle having ragged or sharp edges or
any defect that is liable to injure or hamper the person collecting the waste,
shall be replaced immediately with a new can. Any defective can, when used, may
be taken out of service by the village. The village shall not be responsible
for the cost associated with a replacement container.
(Ord. 88-32, passed 11-21-1988; Am. Ord. 94-14, passed 3-7-1994; Am. Ord. 2005-
41, passed 8-18-2005)
§ 1060.05  NUMBER OF CONTAINERS.
   A sufficient number of containers shall be used to take care of all garbage
and waste that may accumulate between pickups without overloading the
containers. Overloaded containers cause litter on the premises, streets and
alleys, and also produce a breeding place for vermin. Containers shall be
covered or closed at all times.
(Ord. 88-32, passed 11-21-1988; Am. Ord. 94-14, passed 3-7-1994)  Penalty, see
§
1060.99
§ 1060.06  ARTICLES NOT TO BE COLLECTED.
   (a)   No articles of value shall be placed next to or within the immediate
vicinity of waste containers.  The village assumes no responsibility for any
articles placed by the property owner at the curb or next to the trash and
garbage cans.
   (b)   (1)   The following items will not be collected by the village:
         A.   Tires;
         B.   Household hazardous waste including, but not limited to,
automotive fluids, pesticides, fertilizers, solvents, thinners, lawn chemicals,
pool chemicals, cleaners, household or automobile batteries, liquid paint,
prescription drugs, fire extinguishers or propane tanks;
         C.   Radioactive materials;
         D.   Medical waste;
         E.   Explosives;
         F.   Ammunition;
         G.   Gun powder;
         H.   Heating oil tanks;
         I.   Fuel tanks;
         J.   Smoke alarms;
         K.   Roofing materials;
         L.   Computers;
         M.   Electronics; or
         N.   Animal waste that is not contained in a sturdy and leak proof bag
or suitable container.
      (2)   Residents should contact the Hamilton County Solid Waste Management
Agency for advice on the disposal of these items.
(Ord. 88-32, passed 11-21-1988; Am. Ord. 94-14, passed 3-7-1994; Am. Ord. 2005-
41, passed 8-18-2005)
§ 1060.07  LARGE APPLIANCES AND OLD FURNITURE.
   (a)   Large appliances and old furniture shall be picked up on the same day
as normal garbage collection.
   (b)   Mattresses, box springs and any upholstered furniture shall be wrapped
in plastic prior to disposal.
   (c)   For additional collection information regarding these items, the
Village Hall should be contacted.
(Ord. 88-32, passed 11-21-1988; Am. Ord. 94- 14, passed 3-7-1994; Am. Ord.
2018-4, passed 2-12-2018)
§ 1060.08  DEMOLITION DEBRIS.
   (a)   The village shall not be responsible for collecting waste or rubble
resulting from building demolition, remodeling, repairs or construction. A
property owner responsible for causing this waste must arrange for its
disposal.
   (b)   The village will pick up small quantities of such material (i.e.,
drywall, concrete, bricks, dirt or rocks) provided that it is placed in a
proper container and does not exceed 50 pounds.
(Ord. 88-32, passed 11-21-1988; Am. Ord. 94-14, passed 3-7-1994; Am. Ord. 2005-
41, passed 8-18-2005)
§ 1060.09  FEES.
   (a)   A fee of $14 per housing unit in the village (up to five units per
building) per month shall be charged for garbage and refuse collection to the
owner of the premises. The fee shall be included with the residential water
bills that are issued every other month. Multi-family developments of six or
more units are required to privately contract for such services pursuant to §
1060.12.
   (b)   When the fee for garbage and refuse collection becomes due and is not
paid, the Village Administrator may certify the delinquent accounts to the
County Auditor who shall place a certified amount on the real property tax list
and duplicate against the property whose garbage and refuse has been collected
by the Public Works Department but the bill has not been paid. The amount
certified shall be a lien on the owner's property from the date the
certification is placed on the list and duplicate and shall be collected in the
same manner as other taxes so certified.
(Ord. 2007-09, passed 3-1-2007; Am. Ord. 2008-60, passed 12-16-2008; Am. Ord.
2010-67, passed 11-16-2010; Am. Ord. 2013-15, passed 2-25-2013; Am. Ord. 2013-
38, passed 5-21-2013; Am. Ord. 2013-79, passed 12-17-2013)
§ 1060.10  COMMERCIAL-INDUSTRIAL WASTE.
   All commercial, industrial or business locations shall dispose of their
garbage and rubbish by private arrangement with a commercial waste collection
business or through an agreement with the village approved by the Village
Administrator.
(Ord. 88-32, passed 11-21-1988; Am. Ord. 94-14, passed 3-7-1994; Am. Ord. 2010-
67, passed 11-16-2010; Am. Ord. 2013-15, passed 2-25-2013)
§ 1060.11  DEAD ANIMALS.
   Special arrangements for the removal of dead animals can be made by
contacting the Village Hall. The prompt removal by the village will be
expedited if the exact street and house number and location of the carcass is
given. The carcasses shall not be placed in normal garbage or trash.
(Ord. 88-32, passed 11-21-1988; Am. Ord. 94-14, passed 3-7-1994)
§ 1060.12  DUMPSTER REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   Unless alternative arrangements are made with the Village
Administrator, any house, apartment building or similar dwelling with six or
more units is required, at the owner's expense to contract for or provide
dumpster service for the tenants. Dumpster size and service shall be adequate
for the disposal of garbage collected within a one-week period.
   (b)   Unless alternative arrangements are made with the Village
Administrator, a dumpster roll cart or other similar container is also required
for all businesses and commercial or industrial establishments that use five or
more cans to accommodate the disposal of garbage and trash in a week's time.
   (c)   Due to lot size, shape and building location, the village recognizes
that unusual circumstances may exist where it is not possible to locate a
dumpster on the premises. Under these circumstances, a minimum of one can per
unit is required to accommodate the amount of garbage being disposed of, or
enough cans to adequately maintain a business's refuse, garbage and trash.
Dumpsters shall be used if appropriate to this section unless and until
approval to do otherwise is granted by the Village Administrator to the
landlord or business, subject to such conditions as the Village Administrator
may require, which conditions are consistent with the intent and purpose of
this chapter.
(Ord. 88-32, passed 11-21-1988; Am. Ord. 94-14, passed 3-7-1994; Am. Ord. 2010-
67, passed 11-16-2010; Am. Ord. 2013-15, passed 2-25-2013)  Penalty, see §
1060.99
§ 1060.13  TIME LIMITATIONS.
   No person shall place refuse, trash or garbage at the curb or curb line
before 7:00 p.m. on the day before the scheduled pick-up day. If the scheduled
pick-up day is a holiday, the refuse pick-up is the following work day.
(Ord. 88-32, passed 11-21-1988; Am. Ord. 94-14, passed 3-7-1994; Am. Ord. 2005-
41, passed 8-18-2005)  Penalty, see §
1060.99
§ 1060.14  ENFORCEMENT.
   This chapter shall be enforced by the general code enforcement officers of
the village against either an offending tenant and/or the property owner.
(Ord. 88-32, passed 11-21-1988; Am. Ord. 94-14, passed 3-7-1994; Am. Ord. 96-
40, passed 7-16-1996)
§ 1060.15  ORDER FOR PRIVATE REMOVAL OF TRASH.
   The Public Works Director may, at his or her discretion, issue an order to a
property owner to remove trash at the property owner’s expense when quantities
exceed amounts that are usual and customary. The Director of Public Works shall
issue such an order to the property owner either by hand-delivery to the
property owner or by posting of written orders on the premises. If such trash
is not removed within 72 hours of delivery or posting of the notice, the
village may dispose of such trash and assess the costs to the property owner.
(Ord. 2005-41, passed 8-18-2005)
§ 1060.16  VILLAGE DISPOSAL CONTRACTS AND SALE OF CONTAINERS.
   The Village Administrator or, in the absence of a Village Administrator, the
Mayor, may provide for the sale of approved garbage and trash disposal
containers to Lockland residents and businesses by the Village of Lockland. The
purchase of such containers by the village for sale to its businesses and
residents shall be approved as other village purchases are approved and the
Village Administrator or Mayor may establish the price at which the containers
are to be sold based upon the cost to the village, including delivery, storage
and handling of the containers. It is further provided that the Village
Administrator may provide for the pick-up of commercial, industrial or business
garbage and rubbish by the village provided that the owners of such commercial,
industrial or business locations enter into a contract for such a service with
the village which covers the costs of the village as determined by the Village
Administrator based on the cost of the manpower and equipment necessary to
remove the material and deliver it to a disposal site and all costs to utilize
said disposal site.
(Ord. 2013-15, passed 2-25-2013)
§ 1060.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than $500
for each offense.  A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during
or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.
(Ord. 88-32, passed 11-21-1988; Am. Ord. 94-14, passed 3-7-1994)
CHAPTER 1062:  PARKS AND RECREATION AREAS

280.06

   Playgrounds, recreation centers and swimming pools, see Ohio R.C. §§ 755.12
et seq.
   Recreation Board, see Ohio R.C. §§ 755.14 et seq.
§ 1062.01  GENERAL REGULATIONS.
   (a)   Purpose; public park defined.  This section shall govern the use of
all public parks of the municipality.  PUBLIC PARK means any tract of land
owned, operated or used by the municipality primarily for recreational purposes
for the benefit of the residents of the municipality, together with any
adjacent land owned, operated or controlled by the municipality, whether the
land is developed or undeveloped.
   (b)   Motor vehicles. The use of motor vehicles in public parks is limited
as follows:
      (1)   The speed limit shall be ten miles per hour through all park areas.
      (2)   No person shall repair, wash, wax or do any type of work on a motor
vehicle on park property.
      (3)   The parking of motor vehicles is restricted to areas designated for
parking only.
      (4)   No person shall drive a motor vehicle upon any surface in a park
area other than paved surfaces intended for vehicular traffic.  Driving across
ball diamonds or outfields, tennis courts or jogging, walking or bicycle paths
is prohibited.
      (5)   Motorcycle climbing or riding on turf or sidewalks is prohibited.
      (6)   No person shall park a motor vehicle in a public park after sunset,
unless an approved scheduled event is in progress.
      (7)   Unlicensed motor scooters, go-carts, and other vehicles not capable
of being licensed as motor vehicles by the state are prohibited.
   (c)   Alcoholic beverages. No alcoholic beverage is permitted in public
parks, except that the Village Administrator may authorize, by permit, the use
of beer having an alcoholic content of not more than six percent in public
parks, subject to §
1062.02.
   (d)   Fires. No open fire is permitted in public parks, except in grills
provided for that purpose.
   (e)   Littering. No person shall litter or throw trash in public parks. The
waste shall be placed in proper containers.
   (f)   Bicycles. Bicycles are not permitted on baseball diamonds or tennis
courts, or on the walking path in Gardner Park, or on other locations in the
parks which are posted to prohibit bicycles.
   (g)   Activities.
      (1)   All activities in public parks must be scheduled and approved by
the Recreation Board and a permit obtained therefore.
      (2)   All spectators of activities in public parks must stay out of
playing areas during scheduled games or other activities. No spectator shall
stand behind a backstop while a baseball game is in progress.
   (h)   Property destruction. Malicious destruction or removal of vegetation
and/or equipment in public parks is prohibited.
   (i)   Glass containers. No person shall possess any glass container in any
public park.
(Ord. 82-62, passed 6-21-1982; Am. Ord. 94-25, passed 7-11-1994)  Penalty, see
§
1062.99
§ 1062.02  ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES IN PUBLIC PARKS.
   (a)   The Village Administrator shall issue a permit for the use of
alcoholic beverages in public parks only if the conditions set forth in this
chapter are complied with. Any such permit may be revoked at any time if the
Administrator determines that affairs are not orderly and the Administrator may
properly refuse to re-issue such a permit to the same person or organization if
he, she or it is found to be in violation of any of the provisions of this
section.
   (b)   Conditions for selling, dispensing, giving away or consuming alcoholic
beverages are as follows:
      (1)   Any proceeds derived must be used for a specific benevolent
purpose, and so named by the person or persons representing those seeking the
permit, and an organization seeking such a permit must be an established
organization known for such purposes.
      (2)   Application must be made to the Village Administrator and the Park
and Recreational Director at least 14 days prior to the date set for the use of
such alcoholic beverages.
      (3)   The application must be made by a village resident, who shall act
as surety for damage and/or cleaning the premises after its use to the
satisfaction of the Administrator.
      (4)   No alcoholic beverage in excess of six percent by volume of alcohol
shall be sold, given away or consumed under authority of a permit authorized by
this section. Alcoholic beverages, as limited herein, shall only be sold, given
away and consumed in paper or plastic cups. No bottles or cans shall be used
for this purpose.
(Ord. 82-62, passed 6-21-1982)  Penalty, see §
1062.99
§ 1062.03  HOURS OF USE.
   The public parks of the village shall be open only between 6:00 a.m. and
dark, except that Gardner Park shall be open between 6:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m.
No person, other than village personnel conducting village business therein,
shall occupy or be present in such public parks during any other hours. 
However, the Park and Recreational Commissioner may exempt from this section
any groups or individuals taking part in scheduled and organized activities in
the public parks, such as recreational athletic leagues or scheduled festivals
whose events may extend beyond the hour of darkness or 11:00 p.m.
(Ord. 87-35, passed 9-8-1987)  Penalty, see §
1062.99
§ 1062.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter, for which no penalty is otherwise provided, is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than $500 for each offense.  A separate
offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation or
noncompliance occurs or continues.
   (b)   Whoever violates §
1062.01(e) is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree and shall be fined
not more than $500 or imprisoned not more than 60 days, or both, for each
offense.  A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on
which a violation occurs.
(Ord. 82-62, passed 6-21-1982)
CHAPTER 1064:  ALARM SYSTEMS
Section
1064.01   False alarm defined
1064.02   Notice of false alarms
1064.03   Assessment for excessive false alarms
1064.04   Notice of assessment
1064.05   Appeals
§ 1064.01  FALSE ALARM DEFINED.
   “False alarm” as used in this chapter, includes any alarm or report of an
alarm received by the Police or Fire Department of the Village of Lockland that
has resulted from either the mechanical malfunction of an alarm system located
within the village and/or the negligence of the owner of property within the
village and/or his or her agents and/or employees in the setting of the alarm
system, including, but not limited to, those which proximately cause the alarm
to register and be received by or reported to the Police or Fire Department.
Whether or not an alarm or a report of an alarm received by the Village of
Lockland Police or Fire Department qualifies as a false alarm is a decision to
be made by the Chief of Police or Fire Chief of the Village of Lockland, after
proper investigation of the circumstances surrounding said alarm receipt has
been completed by said village officer or by personnel assigned to do so and
report their recommendation to their respective chief.
(Ord. 2012-45, passed 8-21-12)
§ 1064.02  NOTICE OF FALSE ALARMS.
   The Chief of Police and/or the Fire Chief shall give written notice of each
qualified false alarm by regular mail to the owner of the property upon which
the alarm system is located. The notice shall also provide that the property
owner may make a written appeal the determination of a false alarm to the
Village Administrator.
(Ord. 2012-45, passed 8-21-12)
§ 1064.03  ASSESSMENT FOR EXCESSIVE FALSE ALARMS.
   In the event the Police or Fire Department of the Village of Lockland has
received in excess of two false alarms, as more fully defined in §
1064.01, within any calendar year from and after the effective date of this
section, the owner of the property upon which the alarm system is located shall
be charged the sum of $100 per false alarm for each and every false alarm in
excess of two for said calendar year.
(Ord. 2012-45, passed 8-21-12)
§ 1064.04  NOTICE OF ASSESSMENT.
   The Financial Services Manager of the Village of Lockland shall, upon
notification of the Police Chief or Fire Chief, give notice by regular mail to
the owner of the property upon which the alarm system is located, at the
address of record with the Hamilton County Auditor, to pay the $100 per false
alarm assessment. In the event the same is not paid within 30 days after the
mailing of said notice, then said amount shall be determined to be delinquent
and shall be collected in a manner as is authorized by law, unless appealed as
provided in §
1064.05.
(Ord. 2012-45, passed 8-21-12)
§ 1064.05  APPEALS.
   A property owner who has received notice of a false alarm may appeal, to the
Village Administrator, the determination of a false alarm within 30 days of
mailing of the written notice. Upon receipt of a written appeal of a false
alarm determination from the property owner, the Village Administrator, in his
or her discretion, may waive, modify, or set aside the calculation of the
number of false alarms in order to avoid any injustice to the alarm user as a
result of alarm signals which do not constitute false alarms, as defined in §
1064.01. The Village Administrator shall issue a written decision within 30
days of the receipt of the appeal.
(Ord. 2012-45, passed 8-21-12)
